evidence.text: This case arises under the Alien Enemies Act (“AEA”), 50 U.S.C. §§ 21-24; the Immigration and Nationality Act (“INA”), 8 U.S.C. § 1101, et seq. and its implementing regulations; the Convention Against Torture (“CAT”), see Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act of 1998 (“FARRA”), Pub. L. No. 105-277, div. G, Title XXII, § 2242, 112 Stat. 2681, 2681-822 (1998) (codified as Note to 8 U.S.C. § 1231); the All Writs Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1651; and the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

event.doc_name: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: D.B.U. is a Venezuelan citizen who entered the United States through Texas in 2022, and fears returning to Venezuela. ECF No. 2-1 at 1 ¶ 3. He has a single tattoo, which bears his niece’s name. ECF No. 2-1 at 1 ¶ 6. On or about January 26, 2025, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) arrested D.B.U. ECF No. 2-1 at 1 ¶ 4. At the time of his apprehension, D.B.U. was attending a party. Id. ICE and the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) characterized the party as a “Tren de Aragua” party in public communications, and accused D.B.U. as being a TdA member. Id. Following D.B.U.’s arrest, ICE and DEA agents interrogated him regarding his possible TdA membership. Id. D.B.U. denied—and continues to deny—TdA membership. Id.; see also ECF No. 2-1 at 1 ¶ 6. D.B.U. has not been criminally charged. ECF No. 2-1 at 1 ¶ 4.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: R.M.M. is a Venezuelan citizen, born in 2000, who entered the United States at or near Eagle Pass, Texas, in or around 2023. ECF No. 2-2 at 1 ¶ 2. He is married, and has two children, ages six and four. Id. R.M.M.’s wife and children live in Aurora, Colorado. Id. He has several tattoos for personal reasons, including one of his children’s birth years, another of a family member’s name, and one tattoo of religious significance. ECF No. 2-2 at 2 ¶ 10. R.M.M. is “extremely afraid” to return to Venezuela. ECF No. 2-2 at 1 ¶ 4. There, he has protested against the “Maduro regime” and has been harmed by groups “aligned with the regime.” Id. He fled Venezuela because TdA murdered his wife’s father and uncle. Id. He fears TdA will murder him, his wife, and his children. Id. R.M.M. and his family hoped to find “safety and stability” for their family in the United States. ECF No. 2-2 at 1 ¶ 3.
evidence.source_document: Class Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: D.B.U. is a Venezuelan citizen who entered the United States through Texas in 2022, fears returning to Venezuela, and was arrested by ICE on January 26, 2025, after being accused of TdA membership. R.M.M. is a Venezuelan citizen born in 2000, married with two children, fears TdA will murder him and his family, and was arrested on March 1, 2025, after ICE identified him as a TdA member.

evidence.text: Respondents shall provide a twenty-one (21) day notice to individuals detained pursuant to the Act and Proclamation. Such notice must state the government intends to remove individuals pursuant to the Act and Proclamation. It must also provide notice of a right to seek judicial review, and inform individuals they may consult an attorney regarding their detainment and the government’s intent to remove them. Such notice must be written in a language the individual understands.

add_extracted.value: Respondents must provide a twenty-one (21) day notice to Petitioners and the provisionally certified class, stating the government's intent to remove them under the Act and Proclamation, including notice of a right to seek judicial review and the ability to consult an attorney.

evidence.text: the Court GRANTS Petitioners’ Emergency Motion for Temporary Restraining Order. ... (cid:120) Respondents shall not move Petitioners and members of the provisionally certified class outside the District of Colorado. Respondents shall provide a twenty-one (21) day notice to Petitioners and members of the provisionally certified class detained pursuant to the Act and Proclamation.

add_extracted.value: The Court GRANTS Petitioners’ Emergency Motion for Temporary Restraining Order, requiring Respondents not to transfer Petitioners outside the District of Colorado and to provide 21-day notice before removal.

event.doc_name: Petitioners-Plaintiff's Emergency Motion for Temporary Restraining Order

evidence.text: Petitioners-Plaintiffs’ Emergency Motion for Temporary Restraining Order ... Petitioners are civil immigration detainees who are at substantial risk of immediate, summary removal from the United States ... Petitioners move the Court for a TRO barring their summary removal under the AEA and barring Respondents from relocating them outside of this District pending this litigation.
evidence.source_document: Petitioners-Plaintiff's Emergency Motion for Temporary Restraining Order

add_extracted.value: Emergency Motion for Temporary Restraining Order filed April 12, 2025, seeking injunction against transfer outside District of Colorado and 30-day notice before removal

evidence.text: On April 12, 2025, Petitioners also filed their Motion for Class Certification, ECF No. 4.

add_extracted.value: Motion for Class Certification filed April 12, 2025, seeking certification of class including all noncitizens in custody in District of Colorado subject to the Proclamation

evidence.text: On April 12, 2025, Petitioners also filed their Motion for Leave to Proceed Under Pseudonym, ECF No. 3, and Motion for Class Certification, ECF No. 4. ... The Court granted Petitioners’ pseudonym motion. See generally ECF No. 11.
